title: Clean up CLI

labels.name: changelog
labels.description: Issue has been added to the changelog

body:
This makes sure all subcommands get their own module to clean up organization a bit and changes how `load_path` (now `loader::load`) works.

Also adds capture for outputs using `CaptureIo` for tests and benches.

title: Support parsing of a shebang (fixes #270)
Parse multiline comments
body: This also changes so that we create tokens out of comments in anticipation of one day switching to non-destructive parsing. But by that point erroneous comments would also receive their own token instead of using a `bool` to indicate if it's terminated or not.

title: Remove tailing item and unchecked casts
body: Note that unwrapping `try_from` for types which fit (e.g. u32 to usize on 64-bit) compiles down to a cast. But it's necessary to avoid bugs on all platforms.

title: Clean up Call and introduce ExecutionState
body:
So I noted that a `VmExecution` only needs to keep track of two states - whether the current execution is `initial`, or whether it is `resumed`. The latter simply means that the function is a generator or a stream that has been called at least once. While every other function is in the `initial` state.

This is necessary to help top level executions to be correctly managed, because resuming a `resumed` execution requires a value to be pushed onto the stack which will be the return value of the yield statement.

As a result this reverts `Call` back into a sparser state.

title: Fix upgrading guide
body: Thanks @pkolaczk for pointing out the issues in the existing docs!

title: Explicitly drop stack guards to avoid use-after-free issue

labels.name: safety
labels.description: Issue related to safety, like a potential violation of Rust's safety guarantees through public APIs

body:
CC: @pkolaczk to give this a try.

Hopefully fixes #344

I'm trying to come up with a good test for this before merging.

title: Support driving a toplevel generator through VmExecution

labels.name: chore
labels.description: Chores that has to happen for certain tasks

title: Hide more things and improve documentation
Remove underused public trait impls for Id
Rework how opaque identifiers are used
body: Add derive for `Opaque` and rework `Id` into `Id` and `NonZeroId` to ensure that `Id` or `Option<Id>` isn't improperly used as hash keys.

title: Hide more stuff and clean up some APIs
More clippy stuff
body: Since every token has shrunk significantly clippy will no longer complain if we stop boxing everything in `ast::Expr`.

title: Reduce the size of most tokens by inferring ast::Kind
Mark many more things as #[non_exhaustive] and improve parse diagnostics
body:
Mark most things in `rune::ast` as `#[non_exhaustive]` for future proofing.

Parse diagnostics uses a structured `Expectation` rather that static strings which might or might not compose well. This should allow us to avoid scenarios where certain commas or the like aren't escaped since they should be treated as `Expectation::Punctuation`.

title: Native functions no longer requies Copy

labels.name: changelog
labels.description: Issue has been added to the changelog

body:
This removes the requirement that registered native functions are `Copy`, which among other things allows us to build a `CaptureIo` module which does not require `lazy_static` for capturing output.

Also added missing `ToValue` impl for `&str`.

title: Update CHANGELOG.md and start upgrade guide

labels.name: chore
labels.description: Chores that has to happen for certain tasks

body: Started work on the changelog for `0.10.0` and an upgrade guide.

title: Add template literals in an empty group (fixes #326)
body:
This causes template literal desugaring (which happens during lexing) to be desugared into an empty group so that attributes are associated with the internal `template!` macro call rather than the chained expression.

Thanks @Steven0351 for finding and reporting the issue!

title: Fix buggy self value
body: Accidentally renamed the magic `self` variable to `ast` during a refactoring. It would only cause problem if someone actually used a variable with the identifier `ast` though.

title: Introduce #[inststrument] macro
body:
Very simple helper macro that adds the necessary tracing for internal compiler functions.

It's currently limited to trace log every function call, but could eventually be expanded to use `tracing` and spans.

title: More compiler cleanup
body: This just breaks up and clarifies some confusing code paths in the assembling phase of the compiler.

title: Cleanup compiler
body:
A bunch of small cleanups and one big one.

The big change is that this removes the indirection traits used in the `assembly` module in favor of simply calling the relevant functions directly. I.e. the traits are *not* needed. It makes the assembler much easier to understand and patch, because assembling instructions frequently require reshuffling non-local instruction assemblies and now we can simply search in a single source file for every affected caller.

title: store and expose public constants in the unit (fixes #316)
body: @pkolaczk Please give this branch a try! There's a new `Hash::constant` that can be used to make it clearer, as well.

title: replace manual de/ser with derive
body:
So; this proved to be very challenging -- Essentially, removing and/or changing ConstValue::StaticString impacts every API where ConstValue is involved in a ToValue/FromValue call, since one would have to pass a Unit around to resolve the proper index. I don't think it's worthwhile to rewrite all of this, as I'd argue a better approach is to (eventually) create a dedicated on-disk format which shields the runtime from these design decisions. I also don't understand the relationship between ConstValue/IrValue/Value enough to judge what is correct behaviour when these types are converted between each other, and which ones are valid.

My original interpretation is ConstValue was akin to literal (e.g., hardcoded value), and in the case of static string we shunt these to a `.data` segment, like a weak interning. However, this makes it wrong to convert from Value to ConstValue - but removing that breaks a lot of other code, so I think my assumptions are wrong.

Thus, I'll create two issues if this is merged:

* Document the interactions between Value/ConstValue and delimit their use patterns
* Create a dedicated unit format for serialization
